Alternately, these stats could serve as the basis of an entire species of powerful wyvern.

monsterFluff.name: Mitflit
entries: Gremlins are cruel fey tricksters and saboteurs who have fully acclimated to life on the Material Plane. Mitflits, also known as mites, are self-loathing and pitiful cowards with oversized heads, blue skin, and a penchant for befriending the ugliest of vermin as allies.

Of all the types of gremlin, mitflits have the least affinity for magic and have largely lost most of their ancestral gremlin abilities. They find companionship in the other base creatures of the world, and forge bonds of friendship with vermin like spiders, centipedes, and cave-dwelling insects, the only other beings that seem willing to accept them. A social structure, even one in which they are bullied or demeaned, partially fills their need for some type of companionship, and they rarely rebel or against their fellows unless their rage hits a breaking point from which there can be no return.

monsterFluff.name: Mohrg
entries: The weight of murder wears heavy on the soul. With souls marked by a lifetime of dealing death, these killers, whether mass murderers, bloodthirsty soldiers, or sadistic executioners, sometimes do not let judgment and lawful execution stanch their slaying sprees. When such individuals are brought to justice, they might rise after death as mohrgs to continue their work, transforming into skeletal horrors to which strips of decayed meat and unsettlingly writhing entrails cling. The spiny length of gristle and muscle that extends from their jaws like a long tongue is, though, their most disturbing feature.

items.name: Mohrg Spawn
entries: Those who succumb to a mohrg's attacks are doomed to rise as mohrg spawn within the span of what would have, in life, been but a handful of heartbeats.

items.name: Monster Hunter
entries: Be they hunters who have traveled far from their home to chase down legendary prey, or members of a small gathering like the Six Bears, monster-hunting warriors find no shortage of targets to track and hunt in the Stolen Lands. Monster hunters might also resent wandering adventurers, who might kill a targeted monster before the hunters have a chance.

monsterFluff.name: Morrigna
entries: Psychopomps are guardians and shepherds of the dead, and work to guide and protect the souls of all perished creatures on their journey through the afterlife. A wide range of these supernatural creatures dwell in the outer planes, favoring neutrally aligned domains and often gathering in the realms of deities associated with the dead. The least of their kind are small and birdlike, while the most deadly appear more like dragons. Morrignas are more humanoid in shape.

entries.name: Morrigna
entries: Morrignas serve in particular as bounty hunters and investigators who seek out those who attempt to thwart death or interfere with the natural flow of souls. They dress in flowing spidersilk and wear masks reminiscent of webs, as they consider patient and watchful spiders to be their spiritual kin.

monsterFluff.name: Mu Spore
entries: A mu spore is a rare fungoid monstrosity of vast power and strange intellect. Few mu spores are smaller than a hundred feet from tentacle tip to tentacle tip, yet despite this bulk, they are capable of flying with an uncommon grace. Exact appearances can vary, from the form of an immense, almost whale-like leviathan adrift in the air to a seething tangled carpet or canopy-strewn mass of fungus and tendrils.

monsterFluff.name: Mudwretch
entries: In its resting form, a mudwretch looks like a large puddle of thick, dark mud, heaped at the center in a slightly drier patch of loam. When a living creature approaches, though, the mudwretch lurches upward, piling its muddy flesh upon itself to form a roughly humanoid shape, often in vague mockery of the approaching creature's general form in cases where the creature is a humanoid itself. Mudwretches have a low level of intellect, and while they do not form societies or cultures of their own, they are attracted to ruins or abandoned settlements.

monsterFluff.name: Murder of Crows
entries: Crows are common in the Stolen Lands and do not normally pose a danger to explorers of these wilds. Yet when a particularly large flock of them gathers, this murder of crows can become a dangerous threat. Large gatherings of crows are particularly drawn to towns or villages that have been recently abandoned, whether or not there's a large amount of carrion left behind to feed on.

monsterFluff.name: Nabasu
entries: Demons are cruel and chaotic fiends who form from the souls of sinful mortals who have been consigned to the nightmare realm of the chaotic evil outer planes. As fecund as they are destructive, demons remain a favorite type of minion of many a cult. However, those who mistake demons' predilection for chaos as evidence that these creatures are mindless forces of entropy often doom themselves by underestimating these creatures' capacity for subtle manipulation, trickery, and patience when it comes to seeing long-term goals of devastation play out over the passage of time.

entries.name: Nabasu
entries: A nabasu is a cruel monster formed from the sinful souls of evil gluttons, particularly from cannibals, blood-drinkers, and those who prefer to savor the tang of undead flesh. This demon appears somewhat like an emaciated gargoyle in appearance, complete with large batlike wings and jaws full of sharp fangs. Its tiny eyes glow with an unsettling yellow hue.

monsterFluff.name: Ngara
entries: Ngara dwells in Hooktongue Slough and has been manipulating the region's boggards and marsh giants for some time. As with {@creature Engelidis|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 131)}, Ngara would work well as the main villain behind the scenes who manipulates a society for her benefit. Indeed, you can use Ngara's stats to represent less powerful serpent agents of {@creature Engelidis|PKB} if she serves as the primary villain of your plot.

monsterFluff.name: Nilak
entries: Nilak serves the Six Bears as something of a nontraditional leader, but she's exactly what her followers need to recover from their recent troubles. As a druid, her stats work well for any druid, of course, particularly one who focuses more on combat than passive forms of nature worship. Rather than presenting her as an ally to the PCs, you can also adjust her alignment and flavor text to transform her into a vengeful force of nature who seeks to destroy those who dare encroach upon her domain.

monsterFluff.name: Niodrhast
entries: The alien monstrosity Niodrhast has been stranded below Candlemere for centuries, but spent much of that time in hibernation. This creature can also be used as a lurking threat in other ways. They can serve as an ancient menace who remains dormant under an old monastery or other site instead. When civilization encroaches upon Niodrhast's domain, they might wake slowly from their slumber to unleash a vengeful wrath that the PCs will ultimately be forced to quell at the end of a long campaign.

monsterFluff.name: Nishkiv the Knife
entries: Nishkiv is the second-in-command of the Black Tears—a group of assassins and thieves that launches an attack at the very start of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. As with {@creature Kressle|PKB}, you can use these statistics to flesh out members of a larger band of thieves or bandits.

monsterFluff.name: Nok-Nok (1st level)
entries: Nok-Nok sees himself as a goblin legend in the making, although he admits that he hasn't figured out how to get what he wants: to become the fifth of the goblin hero gods and be worshipped by a legion of fearful devotees.

monsterFluff.name: Nomad
entries: The Tiger Lords are the most notorious roving warriors to reside in the Stolen Lands, but other gatherings of nomadic people dwell throughout the region, particularly those hunters who prefer to make the most dangerous monsters of the wilds their prey.

monsterFluff.name: Ntavi
entries: Ntavi's role is to play the part of the bad influence, but with a change to her alignment and personality, she can just as easily play an opposite role as an intimidating but helpful source of advice.

monsterFluff.name: Nuckelavee
entries: When pollution despoils a natural waterway, it draws the dreaded nuckelavee from the First World. This spirit of wrath is a grisly sight: a horselike monstrosity with the gnarled upper body of a humanoid growing directly from its back. Not a patch of skin exists on its form—as if it survived being flayed from head to hoof.

monsterFluff.name: Nugrah
entries: Nugrah is a bitter old man. You can use his statistics to play the part of the sinister hermit who isolates himself in the woods. Perhaps he is a cruel-hearted druid, disenchanted or frustrated that the end of his life might soon come before he completes a specific goal. Or maybe he harbors lifelong regrets about a missed opportunity during his youth that now poisons his mind.

monsterFluff.name: Nyrissa
entries: Nyrissa serves as the primary villain of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. Using her statistics for a foe in another campaign can be tricky, particularly if some of your players have played Kingmaker before. Never underestimate the value of simply changing a foe's name to disguise the origin of its statistics! You can go even further and modify her alignment to good or neutral, perhaps transforming her into a powerful guardian spirit—such as a conscious manifestation of a planet's entire ecosystem. A powerful party of PCs might be called upon to rescue her from even more powerful antagonists bent on enslaving the soul of an entire world.

items.name: Ogre Spider
entries: The terrifying creatures known as ogre spiders often grow as large as elephants. The placement of their eyes above their wide mandibles evokes the grimacing visage of an ogre's leer.

monsterFluff.name: Oleg Leveton
entries: Oleg Leveton is one of the first allies and supporters the PCs meet once they travel into the Stolen Lands. His stats can work well for when you find yourself in need of any local merchant or carpenter.

monsterFluff.name: Ooze
entries: The ravenous oozes of the Stolen Lands often lurk in various types of wilderness, waiting to menace explorers they catch by surprise.

items.name: Overgrown Viper Vine
entries: Rarely, a viper vine that thrives in areas infused with supernatural energies can become extremely overgrown and more powerful, gaining the ability to manipulate vegetation that grows within reach of its sprawling root network. Such an overgrown viper vine gains a lair action.

monsterFluff.name: Oversized Chimera
entries: Chimeras are common beasts in the Stolen Lands, particularly in the western hills and badlands, where they can grow particularly muscular and deadly. While not large enough to be classified as a Huge creature, none would mistake an oversized chimera for a typical specimen, as it stands nearly 8 feet tall at the shoulder and is nearly 15 feet long.

monsterFluff.name: Pavetta Stroon-Drelev
entries: Baroness of Drelev and imperious socialite, Pavetta Stroon-Drelev concerns herself more with excess and comfort than battle. You can use these statistics for a pampered princess, queen, or other upper-class aristocrat, or—after making the appropriate adjustment to alignment and attitude—they can represent a beloved leader or ally. Her dog {@creature Jewel|PKB} might be a different story, though...

monsterFluff.name: Peluda
entries: Peludas are territorial, feral dragons that favor building lairs in reedy marshlands, sparsely forested bogs, and river valleys. A single peluda typically claims a stretch of waterway a few miles in length, often choosing a den somewhere near a river's source. After doing so, the peluda systematically drives off any potential rivals so that they can despoil the land as they please, leaving clawed footprints on muddy riverbanks, littering the ground with sharp scales, toppling trees, and impaling half-eaten corpses on their quills as trophies left to rot. Though protective of their homes, peludas often venture beyond their domains to hunt, roasting prey with their breath or pulverizing them with their tails, burning and killing for cruel sport before slithering, sated, back to their murky lairs.

monsterFluff.name: Phomandala
entries: Phomandala has dwelt in Thousandbreaths long enough to be counted today as a native of the First World. Her powerful nature and magical abilities make her a great choice for a classic tale of a powerful medusa whose reign of terror can be brought to an end only by the most powerful of heroes.

items.name: Piscodaemon
entries: Scions of death by poisoning, piscodaemons are cruel even by daemonic standards, delighting in slow and painful suffering. While poisons and venoms are piscodaemons' preferred tools, their cruel claws are more than capable of tearing enemies asunder if necessary. A piscodaemon is vaguely humanoid in shape, with an octopus-like head, crab pincers for arms, reptilian legs, and a fish-like tail.

items.name: Pitax Warden
entries: While the official guards of the city and kingdom of Pitax are all required to train in various bardic pursuits, their primary role is to ensure that their King maintains control of the land. Clad in their distinctive suits of full plate, they generally avoid using their bardic magic in combat except in acts of desperation.

items.name: Pixie
entries: Insatiably curious, overly excitable, and just a bit puckish, the pixies of the Stolen Lands are more powerful than others of their kind. They are wanderers and tricksters who use their pixie dust to create all sorts of whimsical situations, as well as to defend themselves. Other creatures often have trouble understanding a pixie's rapid, rambling way of speaking.

A pixie of the Stolen Lands looks like a tiny little elf, typically with solid white eyes and clad in clothing or armor made from bits of tree bark, leaves, and flower petals. They flit about on a set of brightly-colored butterfly wings.

items.name: Poacher
entries: Those who seek illegal prey or hope to capitalize on black markets must be capable hunters and have the proper connections within organized society to make a profit from their ill-gotten gains. Their cruel natures and despicable practices make them hated by all who protect the creatures of the forest.

monsterFluff.name: Prazil
entries: The kobold spy Prazil works and his ally {@creature Kereek|PKB} serve as agents of {@creature Hargulka|PKB}. Prazil can serve as the leader of a kobold warren in your game, or even as a member of an adventuring party.

monsterFluff.name: Quelaunt
entries: This three-armed, three-legged monster has no discernible eyes, nose, ears, or mouth and no visible means of ingesting food. Its limbs are distributed evenly across its body such that it is all but impossible to tell which way the creature is oriented at any given time. Few who witness the quelaunt reflect on its alien visage for long, as the most pressing concern quickly becomes an invasion of their minds when the quelaunt sows doubt, sorrow, and rage—drawing sustenance from the psychic trauma of these negative emotions.

monsterFluff.name: Quintessa Maray
entries: Quintessa Maray is a Daggermark spy who has convinced {@creature Hannis Drelev|PKB|Baron Drelev} that she is a poor, exiled noblewoman from Galt in need of shelter. These stats work well for any manipulative aristocrat skilled at getting her way and manipulating society with magic and deceit. They can also be used to represent the leader of a renowned theatrical troupe, a famous traveling entertainer, or even as a provocateur intent on destabilizing an evil regime.

monsterFluff.name: Radiant Warden
entries: The enigmatic and strange radiant wardens were constructed thousands of years ago to protect observatories and scholars against the incursion of alien aggressors from the darkest corners of the unknown universe. Over time, their roles as guardians expanded to include watching over any region where the laws of time and space have worn thin, particularly near portals and permanent gates between planets, planes, or dimensions. Named for both the radial nature of the concentric rings that make up their bodies as well as the glowing radiance of their attacks, radiant wardens carry on their orders, defending sites from invasion with single-minded purpose.

monsterFluff.name: Redcap
entries: Redcaps are sadistic and capricious fey who revel in bloodletting and murder. While they are most famous for appearing as wizened, bearded men, redcap women are no less fearsome or cruel. Redcaps typically stand only 3 feet tall, with hunched frames, pointed ears, crooked teeth, and long, white, tangled hair.

monsterFluff.name: Rezatha
entries: Among the many triumphs {@creature Castruccio Irovetti|PKB|King Irovetti} boasts, the submission of the deadly remorhaz Rezatha is one of his favorites. You can use Rezatha's stats to represent an entire species of particularly powerful remorhazes to challenge high-level PCs. Or—by simply changing the type of energy damage Rezatha inflicts—you can create an entirely new type of creature native to other realms or planes alike.

monsterFluff.name: Rigg Gargadilly
entries: Rigg Gargadilly is a high-strung murderer. While he's encountered in a remote, forgotten ruin in Kingmaker, he'd work well as a supernatural foil against a group of urban-based PCs, for Rigg's talents and predilections would make him a particularly frightening and effective killer. Transplanting him from a remote woodland ruin into the heart of the city gives him an entirely new theme and role in the game without having to change any of his statistics at all.

items.name: Risen Fetch
entries: When a powerful force wills it, echoes of the corrupted soul of a powerful undead creature (be it one that still lives or one that was destroyed within the past 10 years) can be used to spawn a fetch as well. A risen fetch possesses potent magical powers, and appears more as its source did in life than as an undead.

monsterFluff.name: River Elasmosaurus
entries: The elasmosaurus is typically an ocean-dwelling creature, but a larger, more dangerous variant of this primeval reptile has adapted to life in some of the larger waterways of the River Kingdoms. Like its ocean-dwelling kin, the river elasmosaurus has a barrel-shaped body with long flippers and an exceptionally slender neck that ends in a many-toothed, snakelike head.

items.name: Ruffian
entries: The central Stolen Lands east of Hooktongue are well-known for their infestations of small gatherings of bandits. Many of these groups number less than a dozen in all, consisting of ruffians who fled their home towns for various reasons to seek illegal fortunes on the fringes of society. While most of these brigands have enough training and self-confidence to go out on their own, a particularly charismatic bandit lord could still bring them under their heel in the right circumstances.

monsterFluff.name: Sard
entries: An immense, gnarled tree awoken with raw, primal power by one of the fey Eldest of the First World, this monster—one of the legendary Tane—skitters on huge, spidery roots and thrashes its branches as fiery lightning courses within its blackened bark. It's terrifying abilities and visage makes it appear as a living manifestation of the violent clash between ancient forest and stormy sky. Those who claim that there is but a single sard in existence are better classified as wishful thinkers than scholars, but fortunately, these deadly monsters have never been known to travel in groups or ally with others of their own kind.

monsterFluff.name: Satinder Morne
entries: Satinder Morne runs The Velvet Corner in Fort Drelev: a gambling hall that can provide the PCs with a (somewhat) safe place to rest during their mission to the hostile town. Her statistics work well for any innkeeper or similar professional who has hidden talents, such as someone who is a retired adventurer or a cleric of a faith whose interests align closely with industry, society, or intrigue.

monsterFluff.name: Scythe Tree
entries: Malevolent, vicious, and cruel, scythe trees pose as normal trees near deep forest paths, where they wait to slaughter passersby. Instead of drawing sustenance from light and soil, scythe trees gorge themselves on the flesh, blood, and bone of sapient creatures.

Scythe trees are solitary creatures by nature, and their size and power mean that they don't need to compete for food with other carnivorous plants. They appear as dead or dying deciduous trees with long, twisted branches that end in scythe-like blades. Their disturbing mouths remain closed when not eating, resembling little more than jagged gashes on their trunks.

monsterFluff.name: Sepoko
entries: Sepoko is, in theory, the leader of the boggards of M'botuu, but in truth is but a pawn of the naga {@creature Ngara|PKB} {@homebrew |(page 159)}. As a powerful cleric of Gogunta, he can also serve as an unusual cult leader (rather than the pawn of a more powerful manipulator or influencer. Such a mastermind might have moved into the sewers of a large city and attempted to share their faith with members of society's underbelly to form an unusual criminal enterprise.

monsterFluff.name: Shoggoth
entries: The first shoggoths were created by an alien species to serve as mindless beasts of burden. Their vast bulk, incredible strength, and amorphous nature made them useful as supernatural laborers, and their ability to spontaneously form whatever new eyes, mouths, limbs, and other organs they might need made them incredibly versatile. Eventually, the shoggoths developed enough intelligence to rebel against their masters, and now they lurk, patient but potent, in the lightless depths. Made of seething black protoplasm, a shoggoth's actual shape remains a constant chaos of awful, perplexing change.

items.name: Sister of the Bloodshot Eye
entries: The worship of the hag goddess Gyronna is more common in the River Kingdoms than elsewhere in the world. The Sisters of the Bloodshot Eye comprise an even smaller subset of Gyronna's faithful— worshippers who seek to spread hate through the world by manipulating the ancestral beliefs of the unsuspecting. Those found in the Stolen Lands have specialized in corrupting the marauders known as the Tiger Lords.

items.name: Skeletal Champion
entries: These skeletons retain the cunning they possessed in life and fight with great skill.

items.name: Skeletal Hulk
entries: These oversized skeletons are animated from the bones of giants. They originate traditionally from {@creature cloud giant|MM|cloud giants}, but you can use them to represent the animated bodies of any Huge humanoid as well, such as an oversized cyclops.

items.name: Skeletal Tiger Lord
entries: These blood-dripping skeletal champions were raised from the bones of {@creature Tiger Lord|PKB|Tiger Lords}, and while they've lost their ability to benefit from a barbarian's rage, they remain quite dangerous using their bows, blades, and aptitude for slaughter.

monsterFluff.name: Skeleton
entries: Undead skeletons are a well-known but relatively minor threat to those who would explore ancient tombs, but in the Stolen Lands, more powerful variants of these monsters lie in wait. Some of them even retain shreds of their personalities in life, and are capable of much more complicated tasks than the typical necromantic monster most assume they face when a frame of clattering bones rises up to oppose them.

monsterFluff.name: Skulltaker
entries: Swirling down from misty peaks and through howling mountain passes like an evil wind, the vortex of bones known as a skulltaker is a terrible manifestation of the delirium and agony experienced by doomed climbers and lost trailblazers just before they met their end. In some places, a skulltaker is also known as a saxra.

A skulltaker appears as a looming figure, just over 20 feet tall, with an animal's head for a skull, bony human arms and hands, and a body that seems little more than a billowing robe decorated with bones.

monsterFluff.name: Slurk
entries: The slurk is a sticky, tusked frog-beast found in underground lairs and caves. It has two massive tusks that it uses to gore prey and tangle with rival slurks. While these the protrusion of a slurk's walrus-like tusks is certainly the slurk's most distinctive physical trait, the copious amount of sludge and slop exuding continually from its body remains a close second, making the creature look like it just clambered out of a slime pit.

items.name: Snapping Flytrap
entries: The snapping flytrap is a ravenous, carnivorous plant that is quick to bite at any creature that passes by. A much smaller variant than the more deadly giant flytrap, a snapping flytrap typically has a long stalk that ends with two sets of 3-foot-wide leaves, each edged with several sharp teeth.

monsterFluff.name: Soul Eater
entries: Only the most desperate or foolhardy conjurers call upon the aid of these strange fiends from the inky swamps of Abaddon. They appear as inky clouds of darkness from which reach two all-too-solid taloned arms.

monsterFluff.name: Speartooth
entries: The smilodon Speartooth is the type of legendary creature that many trophy hunters spend their whole lives searching for—and die trying to kill. These stats could be used to represent a creature the PCs are sent to hunt, or alternatively, asked to protect from dangerous poachers. You can also use these stats for a species of hearty saber-toothed-tigers, perhaps pets bred for their ferocity by a clan of even more deadly giants.

monsterFluff.name: Spiders
entries: Giant spiders are feared by many, and those that dwell in the Stolen Lands are certainly adept at giving adventurers new things to fear beyond being merely poisoned or caught in a sticky web.

monsterFluff.name: Spirit of Stisshak
entries: This cruel, manipulative will-o'-wisp has been influencing local lizardfolk for some time. The spirit's ability to appear as a long-dead lizardfolk can be adjusted to give it the ability to appear as anything else you require, such as an ancient-but-revered king, a notorious villain, or even the visage of a deity.

monsterFluff.name: Sportlebore Swarm
entries: The bane of hungry adventurers the world over, sportlebores are nefarious vermin that resemble delicious snacks. When positioned near trail rations such as fruit or jerky, a sportlebore can flawlessly imitate these foodstuffs by flexing, contorting, and color-shifting its abdomen, then folding its thorax, head, and legs into hiding under its delicious-looking body. Once consumed, the sportlebore reproduces into a hungry swarm that is regurgitated by the now ailing eater, ravenously attacking any creatures it thinks it can consume.
A single sportlebore can be mistaken easily for a plum, apple, or other juicy-looking hand fruit.

monsterFluff.name: Spriggan
entries: Love, happiness, and beauty have no meaning for nearly all spriggans, for their minds have long since abandoned the capacity to understand and enjoy such positivity in the world. Violence, malice, and distortion have expanded in spriggan society to fill the aching void left behind by their ancient expunging of hope from their culture.

Spriggans resemble muted, hairless gnomes with oversized, pointed ears and a feral appearance. Many of them are gaunt and haggard, with cruel eyes. Their skin tones tend to be varied among many different shades of blue, ranging from a pale sky color to a deep midnight.

items.name: Spriggan Bully
entries: The typical spriggan is a bully who prefers to take live prisoners in fights, if only to ensure that they have a large stock of living victims to torment, tease, and abuse. They train to use weapons in nonlethal ways that inflict the maximum amount of pain even as they guard against accidental death. When not bullying prisoners or hunting for new victims, spriggan bullies enjoy drinking, watching others fight, and fighting among themselves.

items.name: Spriggan Warlord
entries: While the leaders of larger spriggan enclaves tend to be uniquely trained warriors with highly specialized skills, spriggan warlords are fond of the traditional spriggan weaponry of {@item morningstar|PHB} and {@item light crossbow|PHB|crossbow}, valuing this traditional fighting style for its simplicity and for using both weapons to their full potential. Spriggan warlords often serve as sub-commanders in large groups, filling roles in spriggan society akin to captains of the guard or bodyguards to spriggan royalty. In smaller groups or remote outposts, a single spriggan warlord is typically in charge of a band of {@creature spriggan bully|PKB|spriggan bullies}.

monsterFluff.name: Sprite
entries: Elusive, flighty, and ebullient, sprites are what many first imagine when they hear the terms "fey" and "fairy." While there are a wide range of sprites, the largest of them rarely match the size of even a small child—and the vast majority of these wee fey are much smaller.

monsterFluff.name: Stag Lord
entries: The Stag Lord represents the first true "boss" of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}. You can remove the Stag Lord's Perpetual Hangover, restoring him to a CR 7 foe, and have these stats represent an entire group of {@item Stag's Helm|PKB|stag helm}-wearing troublemakers, perhaps led by an even more sinister ruler.

items.name: Stag Lord Bandit
entries: The lowest-ranking members of the Stag Lord's bandits are a mix between soldiers who abandoned their duties and prisoners who escaped into the wild. While the protection the {@creature Stag Lord|PKB} offers is welcome, they still fear their temperamental ruler and tread lightly in his presence.

monsterFluff.name: Storm-Struck Treant
entries: While treants (also known as arboreals) have a reputation for being benevolent (if stubborn) guardians of the woods, those who are struck by lightning or subjected to ages of cruelty can twist and deform into more powerful variants capable of using the very energies that harmed them as weapons. Storm-struck treants look like dead trees—their trunks scarred by blasts of lightning or even charred as if by the flames of a recent forest fire—until they lurch to attack.

monsterFluff.name: Svetlana Leveton
entries: Svetlana Leveton is one of the first allies and supporters the PCs meet once they travel into the Stolen Lands. Her stats can work well when you find yourself in need of a local noble or innkeeper.

monsterFluff.name: Talon Peak Roc
entries: Rocs are legendary beasts, immense birds well known for their ability to carry off sizable prey. However, the roc said to dwell atop Talon Peak in the eastern mountains of the Stolen Lands is reputed to be even larger than normal—and more voracious when threatened by intruders.

items.name: Tarn Linnorm
entries: The two-headed tarn linnorm can wreak an awe-inspiring amount of devastation. They most commonly dwell in remote mountain lakes.

monsterFluff.name: Tartuccio
entries: Tartuccio meets the PCs early on, but hides his true motives from them as best he can. His skill with illusions and trickery could make him an unusual leader of a criminal organization in a small town, or perhaps as a unique specialist working for an organization with greater reach.

monsterFluff.name: Tatzlwyrm
entries: Tatzlwyrms resemble human-sized snakes with two arms and a dragon's head. Distant relatives of true dragons, tatzlwyrms possess only a meager level of intelligence. They can speak, but their ability to reason is limited and they can't use magic. They do possess a level of cunning, however, and some have been known to build rudimentary traps and even lairs.

monsterFluff.name: Tendriculos
entries: These strange amalgams of plant and fungus with animal tendencies form where the natural world is corrupted by foul magic or frayed planar boundaries. Tendriculoses are instinctive ambush predators who seek out lightly traveled forest paths and lie in wait in the undergrowth. They dwell in deep woods and jungles. Those who draw too near populated areas soon attract unwanted attention from their ravenous appetites.

A tendriculos appears as a strange merging of fungus and tree, with a thick trunk atop a twisting mass of coiling roots that remain atop the ground rather than dig into the soil. A mass of long, broad leaves hangs from its boughs, under a "crown" of brightly colored mushrooms. The creature has several vine-like branches that work more like tentacles when capturing prey, and a large mouthlike opening near the top of its trunk that it can use to gulp down those it catches to slowly digest them alive.

monsterFluff.name: Terrion Numesti
entries: When the PCs finally encounter him, Terrion Numesti is a prisoner in need of rescue. These stats work well should you create a rescue mission where the PCs are tasked with locating a relatively high-level NPC and bringing them back alive.

monsterFluff.name: The Beast
entries: The enormous owlbear called "the Beast" should in fact carry the name of the PC's kingdom in its name. In your games, the Beast could well be a regional threat to the realm you've chosen as the focus of your campaign, changing its name to "The Beast of Sandpoint" or "The Beast of Falcon's Hollow" or whatever sounds appropriate. Alternately, the Beast's stats could simply serve as those for a particularly enormous breed of owlbears native to a region in your game.

monsterFluff.name: The First Faithful
entries: The First Faithful is the leader of the sinister Kingdom of the Cleansed, but these stats will also serve quite well for a lone priest of an obscure demon lord, perhaps even for someone filling a role like a notorious killer or other lone menace threatening society from its fringes. Remove his Release the Inmost Worms ability if you use these stats outside of his role in the {@i Kingmaker Companion Guide}.

monsterFluff.name: The Gardener
entries: The Gardener is the ghost of a halfling who has long haunted Whiterose Hill in the western Stolen Lands, not far from the city of Pitax. As with most ghosts, his stats are closely tied to his role in the adventure, but they should work well if you need a powerful foe to lurk in a winery, brewery, or even a haunted tavern of your own design.

monsterFluff.name: The Hateful Hermit
entries: The hateful hermit is a bitter old man who's lived in the Stolen Lands for longer than he cares to remember. By transplanting him from the wilds to the big city, though, he can play the role of a cruel "beggar prince" or other leader of a small-time gang of criminals. In Kingmaker, the hateful hermit is accompanied by a pet puma he simply calls "{@creature Cat|PKB}." Use the statistics for a {@creature panther|MM} to represent this ally.

monsterFluff.name: The Horned Hunter
entries: The Horned Hunter serves as one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} agents, sent to the Material Plane to track down the magic sword {@i Briar}. As a powerful satyr, though, he can certainly play the role of a legendary guardian of an ancient woodland, or even the end boss of a long-term campaign against fey.

monsterFluff.name: The Knurly Witch
entries: The Knurly Witch is one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} more powerful agents in Thousandbreaths. Her statistics can be used as a great foe or final boss in a campaign whose themes revolve around the sinister cult of Gyronna or other evil deity—after making a few changes to her alignment and domains as appropriate.

monsterFluff.name: The Lonely Warrior
entries: The Lonely Warrior is a solo encounter in the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}, but you can use these stats as the basis for an entire category of variant wights to populate a larger, more complex tomb.

monsterFluff.name: The Misbegotten Troll
entries: The Misbegotten Troll is a violent minion of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB}. She often leaves him to his own devices, which run the gamut from cruel to sadistic. He can just as easily play a role where he is no mere minion. He works well in a game that seeks to tell a Beowulf-style story, where a group of high-level heroes are called upon to save a remote kingdom from attacks by an unbelievably powerful giant.

monsterFluff.name: The Nightmare Rook
entries: The Nightmare Rook looms both figuratively and literally over the realm of Thousandbreaths. This strange, supernatural bird can serve in your game as an unusual primary foe and source of mysterious terrors assaulting a kingdom. The more surreal and strange your encounters get, the better, so that when the PCs finally confront the source of these nightmares, the creature lives up to its name.

monsterFluff.name: The Wriggling Man
entries: The Wriggling Man is one of {@creature Nyrissa|PKB|Nyrissa's} closest allies—a powerful wizard whose will to live outlasted his original body and continues on in a colony of writhing worms. He works best as a sinister mastermind in other campaigns, and can fill roles classically portrayed by lich warlords or sinister archmages. Due to his terrifying and unusual appearance, introducing him as a villain in your campaign is bound to keep your PCs on their toes!

items.name: Thorn River Bandit
entries: The least of the bandits in the central Stolen Lands are known collectively as Thorn River bandits— named for the body of water whose banks they prefer to camp along. The local wildlife along the Thorn River isn't as dangerous as in other parts of the Stolen Lands, offering these bandits a safe place to gather and share news.

monsterFluff.name: Thresholder
entries: In the dungeons hidden below Candlemere Island, a cabal of cultists has managed to defeat the passage of time itself. These cultists are known collectively as Thresholders. While they have managed to achieve immortality in their worship of the Outer God Yog-Sothoth, they are also prisoners, trapped within their own hidden temple by an ancient sect of Pharasmins who gave up their life and death to ensure that, while the Thresholders will live forever, they will never escape their own lair. All Thresholders have gained supernatural vision that allows them to see things left unseen, even though this ability required the sacrifice of their eyes to achieve. In addition, their devotion to Yog-Sothoth has pulled them outside of time itself, so that they do not age or need to drink and eat to survive—as long as they do not stray too far from the region where their cult's power is focused.

items.name: Thresholder Disciple
entries: Even the least of the Thresholders are dangerous foes, disciples who work to perfect their bodies as weapons in a perverse parody of the teachings of the monk.

items.name: Thresholder Hermeticist
entries: The hermeticists of the cult are master alchemists whose research into forbidden formulas was a key to pushing their cult to adapt beyond humanity into something far more strange and sinister.

items.name: Thresholder Mystic
entries: Second only in power to their high priest ({@creature Foras|PKB}; page 135), the Thresholder mystics consist of the clerical caste of the cult. Their devotion to Yog-Sothoth and single-minded pursuit of developing a way to allow their eldritch god full access to the Material Plane makes them easily the most dangerous members of the fanatical group.

items.name: Thylacine
entries: The standard thylacine is small and lean, with a set of fang-filled jaws capable of yawning disturbingly wide. It generally has brown fur with tan stripes or spots along its flanks and hind legs.

monsterFluff.name: Thylacine (Generic)
entries: Thylacines are well known dangers of the central Stolen Lands, rivaling wolves in some regions. These creatures are predatory marsupials that look vaguely like lean wolves at first glance—until they stretch open their jaws in almost unnatural displays of aggression.

items.name: Tiger Lord
entries: The most powerful of the Tiger Lords lead larger groups of warriors that dwell in the uplands of Glenebon. These roving warlords have gathered together recently after being deluded by the cult of Gyronna, who tricked them into thinking one of their ancestors, Armag, has returned from death to lead them in a war.

items.name: Tor Linnorm
entries: Tor linnorms dwell in the tallest volcanic mountains, and their tempers can be as hot and destructive as the magma the creature resembles.

items.name: Trapdoor Ogre Spider
entries: In the easternmost plains of the Stolen Lands, giant trapdoor spiders grow particularly large to become behemoths capable of snatching mammoths for meals.

items.name: Tree that Weeps
entries: In the twisted reaches of the dense woodlands in the easternmost reaches of the Stolen Lands, there grow legendary scythe trees known as the trees that weep. These scythe trees are much more powerful and much more sadistic than their lesser kin.

monsterFluff.name: Tristian (1st level)
entries: Tristian has no last name, nor does he have any real memories of his parents. He grew up in a Qadiran orphanage run by a small group of Sarenite priests, and they instilled within him a love of the Dawnflower that helped fill the void left by his missing parents. As he came of age, Tristian left the orphanage to travel the world, eager to spread Sarenrae's blessings and to aid those who, like himself, came into this world seeking a better place in it.

monsterFluff.name: Troll
entries: Trolls are one of the most notorious dangers of the Stolen Lands, be they encountered alone or as members of larger bands. Beyond the typical troll, other more dangerous variants of these creatures can be found in the region, each sharing a penchant for violence, sadism, and murderous cruelty.

items.name: Troll Guard
entries: The ruler of Pitax has recruited a number of brutal trolls to his employ. Arming them with fine armor and weapons and helping to train them further in the art of war has afforded {@creature Castruccio Irovetti|PKB|King Irovetti} with a number of these particularly dangerous palace guards.

items.name: Troll King
entries: Some trolls have learned the skills necessary to survive well beyond the typical life expectancy of their kind and rally others to follow their lead. Troll kings demonstrate a cunning far beyond their younger kin, and can be dangerous foes even when encountered alone. While they look no different than the typical troll, the trophies, armor, and weapons they wear leave no doubt as to their roles in troll society.

monsterFluff.name: Trollhound
entries: Trollhounds are squat, slavering beasts akin to trolls in canine form. Requiring vast quantities of meat to fuel their regenerative metabolisms, packs of wild trollhounds prowl the foothills of regions where trolls dwell, their voracious hunger driving them to slaughter and consume prey. In some regions, trolls breed trollhounds as pets, utilizing the beasts' keen sense of smell to aid in the hunt.
A trollhound looks like a squat, broad-shouldered hound, save that its mostly hairless body has green flesh studded with patches of tan warts and pustules.

monsterFluff.name: Tulvak
entries: Tulvak might strike the PCs as an unusual green hag thanks to her variant spell-like abilities and her disdain of covens. Of course, you can abandon the latter personality quirk to use these statistics to represent the three members of a unique coven of green hags. By swapping out her weapon of choice for another, you can further give a unique spin to this group.

monsterFluff.name: Twigjack
entries: Maladjusted forest denizens, twigjacks form from the cruel and prankish combination of fey and the very woods in which they reside. A twigjack's body is made up of prickly brambles woven with vines. Shaggy, mossy growth, not unlike hair, tops a twigjack's head. Its mouth is just a canyon of splintered and broken sticks bisecting its face. Leaves and sprigs of new growth randomly sprout from the creature's body.

items.name: Two-Headed Troll
entries: Two-headed trolls are dual-minded monsters whose unquenchable thirst for bloodshed is often invoked by parents as a warning to misbehaving children.

monsterFluff.name: Valerie (1st level)
entries: Born into a noble Brevic family, Valerie soon became a shining star of high society. Her father had chosen a great destiny for her: she was to become a champion of Shelyn. However, the teachings of obedience and humbleness before the goddess of beauty and love appealed to Valerie no more than the adoring pursuit of unwanted courters. For many years, she struggled with this against her desire to respect her father, and so she leaned into the martial aspect of her training. Yet one cannot force devotion, and it was only a matter of time before Valerie's patience expired and, in a fit of frustration, she railed against the traditions of Shelyn's teaching, denouncing the concept that beauty and art could ever serve as anything more than hollow praise and delusions of fulfillment.

items.name: Verdurous Ooze
entries: Unlike so many ooze monsters that prefer the darkness of dungeons or caverns, the verdurous ooze prefers to dwell in the wild, slithering through undergrowth as it searches for prey.

monsterFluff.name: Vesket
entries: Thanks to the manipulations of a deceptive will-o'- wisp, the king of the Kamelands lizardfolk, Vesket, grows more cruel with time—drawing treacherously close to fully embracing evil. You can further adjust his alignment as you need depending on the type of lizardfolk king you require for your story. Alternatively, Vesket's stats can be used to represent a member of a rival adventuring group comprised primarily of lizardfolk or other nontraditional ancestries.

monsterFluff.name: Vicious Army Ant Swarm
entries: Army ant swarms are already much feared for their capacity to ravenously consume anything that lies in their path, but even they pale in comparison to particularly vicious army ant swarms. These swarms are often found in desolate tombs, sinister dungeons, or other underground places steeped in dangerous and unsettling traditions.

monsterFluff.name: Vilderavn Herald
entries: In its true form, a vilderavn is a great raven with a wingspan of 6–8 feet. An adaptable shapeshifter, it can change to the fighting forms of a snarling wolf, a hybrid of wolf and raven, or a tall humanoid in black armor with a massive greatsword. Vilderavn heralds often seek to serve those more powerful than typical mortal rulers, and often serve the Eldest of the First World.

monsterFluff.name: Villamor Koth
entries: Villamor Koth is something of a local hero in Pitax, despite the fact that he's done little during his violent life that could be considered courageous. He'd work well as a notorious warrior—be he one the PCs face in combat or one whose respect they must earn to recruit his aid against a deadlier foe.

monsterFluff.name: Viper Vine
entries: A voracious, flesh-eating carnivore, the viper vine has a single enormous blossom arising from a thick, leafy tangle of snakelike vines. When the plant detects the approach of suitable prey through its sensitive, shallowly buried root system, it rises up like an agitated snake and unfurls its brightly colored bloom, releasing a cloud of mind-numbing pollen. Many a story claims the viper vine can lure prey into its clutches by swaying with a hypnotic motion, but this effect is in fact created by this invisible, odorless pollen cloud. The end result, of course, is largely the same to the hapless creature that ends up being eaten by the ravenous plant.

monsterFluff.name: Virthad
entries: Virthad is a particularly mean-spirited doppelganger. As a cleric of Lamashtu, their ability to change shape affords them a layer of subtlety that many villains lack. Though Virthad might adopt any guise—such as the goblin priest reflected in their stat block—who they impersonate in your game is defined by your imagination. Their skill at deception, however, should help them pose as a member of any faith common to the region in which they reside.

monsterFluff.name: Volodmyra
entries: Volodmyra is a mid-ranking member of the Black Tears, and the commander of the attack force sent to invade Jamandi Aldori's manor at the start of the Kingmaker Adventure Path. Her stats work well for any grizzled mercenary, or perhaps even an executioner or torturer in the employ of a cruel overlord.

monsterFluff.name: Vordakai
entries: Vordakai is one of the primary villains of the Kingmaker Adventure Path: a cyclops lich whose power has atrophied to a shadow of his former glory. As with Nyrissa, he's such a memorable foe that transplanting him into other games runs the risk of breaking verisimilitude for any players who have previously played Kingmaker. That said, you can use his statistics to represent a new type of undead creature based on any Large magic-using humanoid, such as an undead ogre magi.

monsterFluff.name: Warsworn
entries: A warsworn is an animate mass of corpses composed of dozens, or sometimes hundreds, of victims of battle. They are formed by deities of undeath or war or, rarely, spontaneously manifest from the devastation of an especially horrendous battle. When the War of the River Kings begins, these immense undead become a dangerous threat throughout the Stolen Lands to soldiers from all sides of the conflict.

monsterFluff.name: Water Elementals
entries: Elementals are outsiders formed of living matter, be it from air, earth, fire, or in the case of the three creatures below, water.

items.name: Water Mephit
entries: Mephits are little bipedal elementals with bat-like wings who serve stronger elementals or, in some cases, spellcasters capable of conjuring them as familiars. Many different types of mephits exist beyond the water mephit detailed below. Mephits are often called upon by spellcasters to serve as familiars; see the entry for {@creature Lintwerth|PKB} (page 155) for one such example.

monsterFluff.name: Wemmuth
entries: Fertilized by large quantities of spilled blood, such as that found on bloodstained battlefields or in the war-torn regions surrounding besieged cities, wemmuths are vile swaths of vines that draw sustenance from mortal suffering, lapping up blood like water. Possessing a rudimentary intelligence and an unquenchable thirst for blood, wemmuths lie in wait for most of their lives, growing to incredible size in the bloody soil of their grisly homes. Though the vines that comprise a wemmuth's body are scarcely thicker than rope, a single adult wemmuth system consists of 6 tons of vines, enough to stretch for 6,000 feet if stretched from end to end in a single straight line.

monsterFluff.name: Werendegar
entries: Werendegar is a type of fey known as a gimmerling. His stats work great as is for a completely unique villain from the First World, with his skills and supernatural abilities making him an excellent choice for a doppelganger-like role in a high-level campaign.

monsterFluff.name: Whimwyrm
entries: Whimwyrms are unpredictable dragons native to the whimsically dangerous First World. While their coloration and appearance might evoke reactions of adoration, their moods shift quickly from one extreme to the other. Many who have assumed that their adorability and relatively small size (as far as dragons are concerned) equates to safety have met swift and grisly ends thanks to a whimwyrm's fangs or magic.

A whimwyrm is a slender, sleek dragon, not much longer than 7 feet from snout to tail, but its speed in combat is unnerving. When a whimwyrm attacks, be it with its fanged mouth or its long tail, it makes several quick, darting snaps or lashes at once. These attacks consist of multiple bites or lashings but resolve as a single Strike. A single attack from a whimwyrm can leave a creature covered in tiny but deep bloody wounds.

Whimwyrms prefer to resolve conflicts with jokes or pranks, hoping to achieve a victory over a foe via humiliation without resorting to combat, but any damage or insult sent a whimwyrm's way is a sure invitation for violent retaliation. A whimwyrm's sense of humor vanishes immediately when it is the butt of a joke, or when anyone implies that they missed the point of a whimwyrm's jest or didn't get the punchline.

monsterFluff.name: Wild Hunt
entries: The wild hunt is an awe-inspiring and enigmatic group of fey who stalk and pursue their prey between worlds. Those few who have caught glimpses of these elusive beings and lived to tell the tale speak of clouds of green mist filled with spectral hounds, archers who fire bolts of magic with inhuman accuracy, and the sound of a melodious horn echoing for miles across the landscape.

items.name: Wild Hunt Archer
entries: These lithe, androgynous humanoids have pointed ears, glowing green eyes, and six fingers on each slender hand. They are methodical hunters who fire their bows with uncanny accuracy, and often rely on {@creature wild hunt horse|PKB|wild hunt horses} to provide increased mobility. Rather than carrying normal arrows, they can produce arrows as needed from magical quivers—these quivers do not function in this manner for anyone other than wild hunt archers.

items.name: Wild Hunt Horse
entries: These powerful steeds stand upon wispy puffs of air, their grassy manes and tails swishing majestically in the wind. When they are not participating in a hunt, wild hunt horses enjoy constructing complicated courses through land and sky and racing each other for ever-changing stakes.

items.name: Wild Hunt Hound
entries: Wild hunt hounds are intelligent hunters and expert trackers that take the lead against elusive prey. Left to their own devices, they seek out creatures that are notoriously difficult to track. They are always surrounded with green mist composed of fragments of the spirits of the wild hunt's victims, a mystic fog that forms itself into a spectral pack to fight at its side.

items.name: Wild Hunt Monarch
entries: Each wild hunt follows a wild hunt monarch, who travels effortlessly between the realm of the fey and the Material Plane in search of new quarry. These limber and regal humanoids have elk antlers, long pointed ears, flowing white hair, and luminescent green eyes.

items.name: Wild Hunt Scout
entries: These compact yet agile humanoids have pointed ears, glowing green eyes, and ram's horns. Wild hunt scouts relish the chance to seek revenge upon those who have wronged or insulted the wild hunt, but they tend to grow bored when the stakes are not lethal. Despite this, they rarely let their bloodlust cloud their judgment when making tactical choices.

monsterFluff.name: Windchaser
entries: Windchaser once served an elderly druid who, on his death bed, granted the horse sapience. You can use Windchaser's statistics for any magically intelligent horse—adjusting his alignment, perhaps, to match that of his rider. You can even use his statistics as the baseline for an entire new species of supernatural steed in your campaign!

monsterFluff.name: Winged Owlbear
entries: Owlbears—iconic beasts well known for their strange duality—can grow to immense size on the First World. The addition of a vast pair of feathered wings seems almost natural to such an evolution of their kind.

monsterFluff.name: Wyvern
entries: Wyverns are the most commonly encountered drakes within the Stolen Lands, although they tend to prefer the westernmost or easternmost reaches of the region as their hunting grounds.

monsterFluff.name: Xae
entries: Xae lost her life in the pursuit of a legendary competition held by one of the Eldest, and lingers after death as a ghost. She works best when the story supports the themes intrinsic to her backstory. However, you can also use these statistics to represent a brand new type of undead in your game, such as an incorporeal spirit who has been untethered from time itself. In this case, consider having Xae come from some strange dimension or other reality from the far corner of the multiverse.

monsterFluff.name: Xill
entries: Xills see Material Plane creatures as little more than incubators, but their driving need for fresh hosts never abates, for on their home plane, xills are constantly at war. Only the relative emptiness of the Ethereal Plane keeps their conflict with others from becoming too overwhelming and outpacing the incredible speed at which new ranks of soldiers can replace those who have fallen. These four-armed, warmongering monsters paralyze their victims before implanting them with eggs using an ovipositor normally kept retracted behind their mandibles. Their single-minded drive to expand and conquer is so all-encompassing that while they work together dutifully and without dissent, there is little else in their lives.

Xills have dark red, almost purple flesh, and while many of them wear armor-like clothing made of strange dark material, their supernatural flesh affords them all the protection they need in many environments. Their four arms, elongated faces, twisted jaws, and ropy lengths of tendrils in place of hair leave most scholars with no doubt as to their fiendish natures.

monsterFluff.name: Zombie Hulk
entries: Zombies might move slowly, but one shouldn't underestimate the danger posed by these ever-hungry undead.

entries.name: Zombie Hulk
entries: Only slightly less dangerous than cyclops zombies, these immense hulking undead foes are nonetheless dangerous creatures that possess terrifying strength. They are typically animated from the remains of huge giants.

monsterFluff.name: Zomok
entries: Mighty and mysterious plant-dragons, zomoks prowl the woodlands, defending their homes from destructive forces while healing and restoring their forests following natural disasters and ravaging intruders. Zomoks vary in appearance with the seasons, growing verdant green in the spring and summer, changing to autumnal colors of fiery red and orange in the fall, and decaying to brown in winter. Regardless of the season, though, their general shapes are those of immense, often somewhat rotund-looking dragons. While zomoks can and often do swallow their foes, they have no real need to eat them.

monsterFluff.name: Zorek
entries: Zorek is an ageless guardian who watches over a tomb. As a devotee of Gorum, he works best in other games as a guardian of any site sacred to a chaotic god of war—such as a tomb of honored fallen warlords. However, his stats could be used for a guardian of an active shrine or a famous landmark said to have been touched by the god of war in ancient times.

legendaryGroup.name: Nyrissa
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), but no more often than once per minute, Nyrissa can take a lair action to use the following magical effects:

items: If she's located in the 20-foot diameter central area of one of the four Fables (see page 475 of the {@i Kingmaker Adventure Path}), Nyrissa moves a minimum distance of 10 feet, after which the reality of the demiplane folds around her in a tangle of vines and flowers. She then teleports from her current Fable to one of the other three of her choice, appearing in a square of her choosing within the central 20 feet of the chosen Fable.

legendaryGroup.name: Overgrown Viper Vine
lairActions: When fighting inside its lair, an overgrown viper vine can use its root network to take the following lair action. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the viper vine can cause the following effect.

items: The viper vine writhes its root network, causing one creature of the viper vine's choice that is standing on the ground within its lair to be attacked by manipulated foliage. That creature treats the square it is standing in as difficult terrain until the end of its turn, and must attempt a {@dc 17} {@homebrew Dexterity|Reflex} saving throw. On a failure, the creature is knocked {@condition prone} and is {@condition grappled} until the end of its next turn.

trap.name: Ballista Defense
entries: This is one of several ballistae that augment the defenses of King Irovetti's Palace in Pitax. If the alarm is raised while the PCs approach the palace, guards ready and load the ballista firing on any targets within range on their initiative. With a team of at least three guards attending the ballista, the weapon can be reloaded and fired each round.

entries.name: Ballista
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h} 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage.

The ballista has AC 15 and 50 hit points. However, it fires through an arrow slit in the castle wall and has three-quarters cover from attacks originating from outside the wall. Attempting to sabotage the ballista's firing mechanism through the arrow slit from outside the wall requires a successful {@dc 25} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check. If the same check is attempted from inside the room with the ballista, the DC is 15.

There are four guards stationed at the ballista. If two or more of the guards are made to leave their post or are incapacitated or killed, the efficiency of the ballista is compromised. At least three guards are needed to maintain its optimal firing rate. If only two guards attend the ballista, they must spend an action to reload and aim, allowing the weapon to fire only every other round. If only a single guard attends the weapon, they must spend an action to reload, another to aim, and one to fire, allowing a shot only once every 3 rounds.

trap.name: Breath of Despair
entries: {@i Complex Trap}

The faces carved into the wall exhale slithering tendrils of darkness that writhe and coil in the air. When a non-flying creature moves more than 10 feet into the area, the trap triggers, causing the stone faces to inhale and sap energy from those in the area. All creatures in the affected area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) necrotic damage and becoming enfeebled on a failed save. While enfeebled, a creature deals half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength, and has disadvantage on Strength checks. The enfeeblement lasts until a creature finished a short or long rest, or until removed by {@spell greater restoration}. On a successful saving throw, a creature takes half the amount of damage and is not enfeebled.

At the start of the next round, the stone faces exhale a despair-inducing breath. All creatures in the affected area must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage and becoming {@condition frightened} until the end of their next turn on a failed save. A {@condition frightened} creature must take the {@action Dash} action to move out of the area by the safest route it can see, unless there is nowhere for it to move. On a successful saving throw, a creature takes half the amount of damage and is not {@condition frightened}.

The trap continues this cycle of inhaling and exhaling as long as a non-flying creature remains in the area, ceasing if there are no creatures in the area for 1 round. Then the trap resets itself after 1 minute.

The trap can be detected with a successful {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check and disarmed with a second successful check. A failed check triggers the trap. Detect magic reveals an aura of necromantic magic around the faces in the wall. A successful {@spell dispel magic} ({@dc 15}) cast on the faces destroys the trap. A single face has AC 17, 10 hit points, and is immune to poison and psychic damage. Completely blocking the mouths of all four faces or destroying all four faces disables the trap.

trap.name: Breeg's Traps
entries: Several dozen hidden bear traps are scattered across this area. A trap is triggered when a creature steps on it, causing the trap to snap shut on the creature's leg. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage and is {@condition restrained} so long as the trap is spiked into the ground. The trap can be pulled loose from the ground with a successful {@dc 12} Strength check. The creature is no longer {@condition restrained} but moves at half movement until the trap is removed from its leg. A creature, whether the trapped creature or an ally, with hands or other manipulative digits can make a {@dc 13} Strength check, removing the trap from the creature's leg on a success. A failed check deals another 2 piercing damage to the trapped creature.

The traps are hidden beneath undergrowth and leaf litter, requiring a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to notice. Once aware of a trap, a creature can safely disarm it by applying force to the pressure trigger, pushing on it with a staff or other object, or tossing a heavy object like a stone onto the trigger.

A PC must succeed at a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check to locate and disable all the traps in this area. The traps can be reset and triggered up to 5 times before they are considered used up.

trap.name: Camouflaged Spiked Pit
entries: This is a 20-foot deep, funnel-shaped pit lined with dozens of wooden spikes and camouflaged by a cloth covered in dirt and twigs. A creature must make a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to notice the pit. A creature moving onto the cloth falls into the pit unless they succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage from rolling down the steep decline, plus 22 ({@damage 4d10}) piercing damage from contact with the spikes on the way down.

Once a creature has fallen into the trap, or the discovered cover has been removed, it is no longer camouflaged until the covering has been replaced. The pit is easily seen and avoided once uncovered, but the only way to disable it is to fill in the hole.

trap.name: Collapsing Bridge
entries: This bridge is old and in disrepair. A single broken support will cause the bridge to groan, shake, and then collapse. A support has AC 15 and 5 hit points. If a support is destroyed, any creature on the bridge between the red dotted lines falls 30 feet, into the water or on land, depending on its location. A falling creature must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage from the fall and 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage from falling debris on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A creature beneath the bridge when it collapses must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage from falling debris on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The bridge cannot be stabilized without full repairs to the structure, which could take weeks. Spells such as {@spell wall of stone} or {@spell wall of force} could provide much more immediate, if temporary, support to prevent collapse.

trap.name: Collapsing Floor
entries: If a Small or larger creature walks into either five-foot square at the westernmost end of the building, the floor collapses, dropping the creature and rubble into the depths below unless the creature succeeds on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) bludgeoning damage from the fall, plus an additional 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage from the collapsing timbers.

A successful {@dc 19} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check must be made to notice the weak wall supports surrounding the floor. These areas can be jury-rigged with supports to prevent the collapse with a successful {@dc 19} Dexterity check. A failed check triggers the floor's collapse.

trap.name: Cutthroat Haunt
entries: The pain endured by Abbot Ildeben as {@creature the Gardener|PKB} cut his throat lingers in this room. If a creature comes within 5 feet of the bloodstain in the center of the room where Abbot Ildeben died, a spectral sickle manifests behind that creature and attempts to cut the creature's throat.

A creature that has its throat cut in this way must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature taking damage in this way has its hit point maximum reduced by the amount of damage it took. This reduction lasts until the creature takes a long rest. Once this haunt manifests, it won't manifest again for another hour.

A creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) ability check to appeal to the haunt and convince it that the party isn't the source of its pain. A creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) ability check to rebuke the haunt in Cayden Cailean's name. If either check is successful, the haunt is disabled and will not manifest again.

trap.name: Dread Aura
entries: A disturbing sensation of having attracted the unwanted attention of something unimaginably powerful grows increasingly overwhelming as a creature lingers in the area.

A creature ending its turn in the ruins of the tower while not currently affected by the Dread Aura must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or feel as if it has attracted the attention of something very powerful. A creature that fails this saving throw has disadvantage on all saving throws against effects that would make it {@condition frightened} so long as they remain within the hex containing Candlemere. A creature that succeeds its saving throw is immune to the Dread Aura for 24 hours.

A creature that succeeds on a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) ability check can inscribe eldritch warding sigils on the stones of the tower, disabling the Dread Aura. Alternatively banishing the Thresholder influence in the chambers below will cause the Dread Aura to dissipate.

trap.name: Dropping Web Trap
entries: A 30-foot-wide web bridge spans a 30-foot-deep mountain chasm. A creature who succeeds on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check recognizes the bridge is in fact loose. The bridge collapses when one Large, two Medium, or three Small creatures move onto the it. Creatures on the bridge when it collapses fall 30 feet and take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage.

Securing the bridge in place so that it can be crossed safely requires a creature to succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. Once the bridge has collapsed, a creature must succeed at a {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check to set it up again.

trap.name: Eldritch Echoes
entries: Eerie sounds ring out and those who listen for too long become convinced that these forces can be defeated by lashing out at them, even though whatever or whoever is responsible is not apparent. When at least two creatures who aren't native to Thousandbreaths end their turn in the area, those in the room begin "hearing" the sounds in the room telepathically and start to have difficulty telling the difference between these sounds and those of their allies.

The trap starts scrambling senses and forcing creatures to perceive threats to their very place in time and space where no such threats actually exist. Every creature in the area must make a {@dc 19} Wisdom saving throw at the end of each of their turns. Creatures that fail this saving throw become confused as per the {@spell confusion} spell until the end of their next turn. Creatures that succeed the saving throw are unaffected.

A creature that succeeds on a {@dc 19} Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) or Charisma ({@skill Performance}) ability check counters these eerie sounds by exceeding their influence, startling the echoes into silence with a dazzling display or fit of rage. Once disabled, the trap does not manifest again.

trap.name: Endless Struggle
entries: Vicious spirits of owlbears and bandits rise up and resume their grisly battle. These spectral figures manifest in a sudden and overwhelming battle of endless violence. The spirits have AC 16, 66 hit points, immunity to necrotic damage, vulnerability to radiant damage, and resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks.

The spirits appear when three or more creatures that are Small or larger enter the area. The spectral violence churns and flashes through the room, targeting three separate creatures with ghostly claws, beaks, swords, and arrows. The haunt makes a magical attack against these three creatures with a {@hit 9} bonus, dealing 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage on a successful hit. Additionally, all creatures in the area must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of the ghostly apparitions.

A creature must succeed on three {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) ability checks to empathize with the bestial spirits and calm them or succeed on two {@dc 16} Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) ability checks to exorcise the haunt and disperse its energy. If disabled or destroyed, the haunt will reset after 24 hours unless {@creature the Beast|PKB} has been slain.

trap.name: Explosion Bear
entries: This animated bear starts to dance, with a magical rune seemingly controlling its movements. The bear has AC 19 and 40 hit points.

The bear dances for three rounds, after which it explodes. Creatures within a 20-foot radius of the bear must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 99 ({@damage 18d10}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The trap is disabled if either {@creature Nyrissa|PKB} says the words "good bear" to the trap before it finishes its dance, {@spell dispel magic} is cast on the rune (treating it as a 5th-level spell), or a PC succeeds on a {@dc 19} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) or Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) ability check to erase the rune. A failed ability check sets the explosion off prematurely, as does reducing the bear to less than 20 hit points without reducing it to 0 hit points.

trap.name: Falling Portcullis
entries: A trip wire under the arch causes the keep's ancient portcullis to slam down, sealing the entrance and alerting the denizens of the keep to the intruder's presence. The portcullis has AC 15 and 56 hit points. The tripwire can be spotted with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, and disabled with a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) or Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check.

If the tripwire is pulled or severed (typically through the action of a person walking through the archway into the area beyond), or an attempt to disable it fails, the portcullis comes crashing down. Any creatures passing under the portcullis or standing below it must attempt a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage. Once the creature takes this damage, the creature is thrust aside to an adjacent square of the PC's choice.
Once the portcullis falls, it can be lifted by a creature who succeeds on a {@dc 20} Strength ({@skill Athletics}) ability check or via the nearby winch.

trap.name: Flooding Room
entries: When the southern secret door is opened or any of the trapdoors in the ceiling are forced open, this trap is triggered. As soon as this occurs, the portcullises to the north and south come crashing down, each consisting of solid iron sheets that form watertight seals. At the same time, the dozen 5-foot-wide trapdoors open in the ceiling. These holes are the mouths of winding tunnels that connect to a second pair of apertures on the submerged side of the island outside, allowing the waters of the Little Sellen River to plunge down into this room, possibly damaging or knocking prone those in the square portion of the room itself (but not in the adjoining hallway) and eventually flooding the entire chamber.

A successful {@dc 16} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check is required to disable one of the 12 trapdoors and seal it shut; disabling all 12 doors completely deactivates the trap. A {@dc 14} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check is required to disable one of the watertight portcullises. Spells such as {@spell stone shape} or {@spell wall of stone} can also be used to disable parts of the trap at the GM's discretion. Each portcullis has AC 16 and 70 hit points.

When the trap is triggered, the two secret doors to the cyclops zombie alcoves spring open, releasing zombies into the room. Any creature standing in the central 40-by-40-foot section of the main room must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage from the rushing water. Once the cascade begins it is easy to avoid the flow of water but a creature that deliberately enters the cascade takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage.

If all 12 trapdoors are open, the room fills with water at a rate of 1 foot per round. If one of the portcullises is breached, or half of the trapdoors are closed, the trap fills the room at half the rate, and if both occur, it fills at one quarter the rate. The flooding ends and the trap deactivates once the area is filled to the ceiling—at this point, the floodwaters equalize with the external environment and do not continue to flood the rest of the dungeon, but creatures still trapped in the room begin drowning. A Medium or smaller creature can try to swim to freedom through one of the 5-foot-wide tunnels leading to the river but doing so requires navigating 200 feet of flooded tunnels.
This trap cannot be reset without the completion of a major engineering effort.

trap.name: Frozen Moment
entries: {@i Complex Trap}

Warding magic attempts to trap intruders or would-be thieves in a temporal disruption. A creature that touches the warded object or area triggers the trap, and all creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be trapped in a disrupted time flow. Affected creatures' minds move so quickly that each round seems to last a century, but their bodies and magical energies move so slowly that they can't take actions. An affected creature can make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw for every minute of real time that passes while the creature is trapped in the frozen moment, ending the effect on itself on a success.

The magical ward can be spotted with a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. A creature that succeeds at a {@dc 20} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check disables the trap, though a failed check triggers it. {@spell Dispel magic} can negate the trap as it is triggered or can end its effects for a single creature, treating the trap as a 9th-level spell.

trap.name: Greater Glyph of Warding
entries: A creature attempting to open the desk drawer or the secret door to the nearby area triggers the associated glyph. The {@spell glyph of warding} targets the creature with a {@spell finger of death} spell (save {@dc 20}).

The warding can be spotted with a successful {@dc 20} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. A creature that attempts to remove the glyph must succeed on a {@dc 20} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check to disarm it without triggering it. {@spell Dispel magic} can negate the trap as a 6th-level spell.

trap.name: Hidden Pressure Plate
entries: A creature that steps onto the pressure plate causes the doors to the four nearby rooms to open, allowing the {@creature goblin bat-dog|PKB|goblin bat-dogs} to escape.

Creatures can notice the plate with a successful {@dc 13} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, and a successful {@dc 15} Dexterity ({@item thieves' tools|PHB}) check renders the pressure plate nonfunctional. A successful {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check locates a hidden switch that deactivates the pressure plate.

trap.name: Lights of the Lost
entries: {@i Complex Trap}

Slain priests manifest as balls of floating, blood-red wine, each offering a glimpse at the visage of a face screaming silently within. A creature opening any of the doors into a priest's cell activates this trap.
